name: Tropical Pitcher Plant
description: Nepenthes ventricosa, commonly known as Pitcher Plant or Monkey Cup, is a carnivorous plant native to the Philippines, particularly in high-altitude tropical forests. It belongs to the Nepenthaceae family and features modified leaves that form distinctive pitcher-shaped traps (10-30 cm tall) filled with digestive enzymes. The pitchers are typically green to red with a waxy interior that prevents prey from climbing out. The plant displays an upright, climbing or bushy growth habit and typically reaches 10-30 cm in height. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers. In its native habitat, it grows as an epiphyte or terrestrial plant in nutrient-poor soils, supplementing nutrients by trapping and digesting insects. Some larger species can trap small vertebrates. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds unique, fascinating carnivorous interest. It's popular among carnivorous plant enthusiasts for its distinctive pitchers.

Feeding optional - catches insects naturally, but can be fed small insects occasionally
